title: 100 followers question
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Delta PQR"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the pedal triangle of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Delta ABC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Excenters of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Delta PQR"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(20,8), (4,12), (13,1)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If one of the vertices of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Delta PQR"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(14,2),"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" then find the area of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Delta ABC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Details and Assumptions:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Pedal triangle of a triangle is formed by joining feet of altitudes to the sides of the triangle."}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"An excenter of a triangle is a point of intersection of an internal angle bisector and two external angle bisectors of the triangle. "}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note: Try to solve this within a minute."}]}]}

title: 100 followers special
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/solvable/d55e6c8537.e49512524f.BiUWhm.jpg?width=250"}},{"type":"text","text":"
A dog sees a rabbit running in a straight line across an open field and gives chase. In a rectangular coordinate system (as shown in the figure), assume:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(i) The rabbit is at the origin and the dog is at the point "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(L,0)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" at the instant the dog first sees the rabbit."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(ii) The rabbit runs up the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"-axis and the dog always runs straight for the rabbit."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(iii) The dog runs at twice the speed of the rabbit."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Assuming "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"L=300"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" units, how much does the dog have to travel to catch the rabbit?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Enter your answer as the distance the dog has traveled from sight to meal."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Yes I agree with Ronak.There is a similar question in IE Irodov."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"https://i.imgur.com/dHUVxxG.png"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"dx/dtdx/dtdx/dt","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" in the rate at which separation between dog and rabbit decreases. 
From the figure
in vertical direction"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"−dx=(2v−vcosθ)dt-dx=(2v-vcos\theta )dt−dx=(2v−vcosθ)dt","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\int _{ 300 }^{ 0 }{ -dx } =\int _{ 0 }^{ t }{ (2v-vcos\theta )dt }"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"300=2vt-v\int _{ 0 }^{ t }{ (cos\theta )dt }"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"..........(1) "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"in horizontal direction"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"vt=2v\int _{ 0 }^{ t }{ (cos\theta )dt }"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\int _{ 0 }^{ t }{ (cos\theta )dt } =\frac { t }{ 2 }"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"putting this value in eq (1)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"300=2vt-\frac { vt }{ 2 }"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"t=\frac { 200 }{ v } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"On multiplying this velocity of dog we will get the distance="},{"type":"text","text":"400","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            How did you get the 2v-vcos(theta)? Wouldn't it just be 2vsin(theta)?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First of all, I'd like to thank all the "},{"type":"text","text":"100","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" followers that have seen me as worthy of being followed. I have more awesome problems coming up in the future, so STAY TUNED XD"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"And now, a tribute:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"http://gifsec.com/wp-content/uploads/GIF/2014/02/GIF-That-awesome-moment.gif"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hope that's "},{"type":"text","text":"all the time","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" for you. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, back to our problem. I'd like to see if this problem is fool-proof (no shortcuts or weird tricks). This is actually the 4th part of the question, and thus having skipped the first 3 that guide to answer the 4th, making it more difficult. But it's not impossible to answer this question without answering the first 3. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I've taken this problem from the "},{"type":"text","text":"Differential Equations","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" chapter of Stewart's Calculus 6E. It will be posted somewhere on a wall in my school for a 50$ prize. Obviously this is directed towards the math teachers (for reasons), whom I wish to embarrass. I know cannot handle anything of this difficulty. But I can (with the solutions manual at my disposal xD)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So please check this out for me and tell me if it is a difficult one. (I didn't exactly dive into it, just skimmed). The solution sure seems not straight-forward. Here are the 3 sub-problems for those who are wondering:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The posted problem (here's the exact wording: "},{"type":"text","text":"Suppose that the dog in Problem 9 runs twice as fast as the rabbit. Find a differential equation for the path of the dog. Then solve it to find the point where the dog catches the rabbit.","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":") is a modified continuation of the original problem, where in the original the dog is as fast as the rabbit."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(a) Show that the dog's path is the graph of the function "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y=f(x)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" satisfies the differential equation"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x\frac{d^2x}{dx^2}=\sqrt{1+(\frac{dy}{dx})^2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(b) Determine the solution of the equation in part (a) that satisfies the initial conditions "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y=y'=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=L"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". ["},{"type":"text","text":"Hint","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":": Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z=dy/dx"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in the differential equation and solve the resulting first-order equation to find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"; then integrate "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".]"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(c) Does the dog ever catch the rabbit?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I shall post solutions upon request."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Cheers"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @John M. – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" John, if the rabbit has gone 200 feet (in your problem) before the dog catches ujp with it, then obviously the dog went 400 feet. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Michael Mendrin – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" oo rlly? cause doesnt determining how far it travels also determine where it catches it? mhmeh then I could make it a general problem for when the dog is n times faster! but then I doubt solutions will exist LOL"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"but yeh if you wanna have fun on brilliant just wait till I have vacation I'ma pull up my communist russian math books with calculus math problems that some of great math professors of the time have struggled with! but now I'm taking a break. I will not be returning to brilliant probably for a year, or occasional vacations. maybe conceptual physics once in a while."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"thx for all"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"cheers","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            John, when One Top referred to this book and solution, and I looked it up, I recognized the book as one of mine in my pile of books in the garage somewhere.  One of these days, I need to go pull out all those books, and then I'll have even more fun on Brilliant.  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"But in fact, it turns out that the ratio of the speeds of the dog and rabbit is cirtical. If it's exactly 2 to 1, then as readily solvable as shown in that book.  Otherwise, the solution gets less neat.  The "straight line pursuit problem" is probably the most basic pursuit curve problem there is, and already it's a really messy problem. It might interest you to know that the Air Force do have extensive studies on the problem of pursuit curves, for I guess pretty obvious motivations.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            So that's how you solved it, huh. Yeah I saw the link. That's pretty disappointing :/"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I guess there is no way to make someone go through all these steps with just one problem after all.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            oh whoa what a huge shortcut! No complicated calculus whatsoever! dang, thanks a lot! This problem isn't worth 50$ after all (I even wanted to make it 100$)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"And a great link by the way! You should share it as a note."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Cheers

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Please refer to  "Ingenious" by L.A Graham, Problem #74 called Fido-Tabby Chase. This book is available on the net here: http://www.scribd.com/.../Ingenious-Mathematical-Problems...

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

replies.body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @John M. – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" Your welcome. The solution Michael references is a nice surprise; I'd never seen it done like that. Anyway, according to the equation at the end we have the rabbit traveling"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{2*300}{2^{2} - 1} = 200"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" units,"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"so since the dog runs at twice the speed it will have covered a distance of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"400"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" units by the time it catches the rabbit. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Brian Charlesworth – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" Mhm I see. I will review this further and change the problem accordingly."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thank you. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            The magnitude of the displacement vector is the 'straight line' distance between the starting and finishing points, i.e., from point "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to point "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Since the dog travels along a pursuit curve he travels a distance greater than the magnitude of the displacement vector. At least that's how I was taught. :)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I figured that you wanted the distance traveled, since the answer had to be an integer, and in this case the magnitude of the displacement vector is not an integer but the distance traveled is.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            O-oh? I thought displacement is how much an object goes through space, no? Or is it the distance from point "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to point "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Sorry for being picky, but your use of the word "displacement" confused me momentarily. I still entered the distance the dog traveled, (400 units), as my answer, but displacement is a vector, and in this case the displacement vector "from sight to meal" would have a magnitude of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sqrt{200^2 + 300^2} = 360.56"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" units to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" decimal places.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Plz can you post some detailed solution which is simple

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 100 followers special
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"let x is the number of the factors of 100"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"let y is the sum of the first 100 positive integers"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"let z is the number of zeroes in 100!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"compute x+y+z"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"IT WILL BE BETTER IF YOU CAN CHANGE YOUR STATEMENT;
SUM OF FIRST HUNDRED INTEGERS TO SUM OF FIRST 100 NATURAL NUMBERS","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"SOLUTION:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(a) Number of factors of 100"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=100 can be written as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"text","text":"X","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5^{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=Therefore, no. of factors"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"="+1" the power of prime numbers"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=(1+2)(1+2)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{9}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(b)1+2+3.....+99+100"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{n(n+1)}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{100(101)}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{5050}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(c)no. of trailing zeros:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{100}{5}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{20}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{20}{5}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 
="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(divide any given positive integer repeatedly by 5 until it gets divided by it to find the no. of trailing zeroes.)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"therefore, the answer is:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{9}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"+"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{5050}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"+"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{20}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"+"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{5083}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            FYI - You can update your question by clicking on the dot dot dot menu and selecting edit. This will allow you to fix any issues with the problem, and make it clearer for others.

                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            There's a difference between "trailing zeroes" and "zeroes"; 1050 has two zeroes in it but only one at the end.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I can't believe I didn't count 100 as a factor of 100. Also, 100! contains more zeroes than the 24 at the end.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            it is stated in the problem that y is the sum of the first 100 integers. why is it that you did not start in 0?  it is not stated in the problem that y is the sum of he first POSITIVE integers...  please correct me if i'm wrong... thanks

title: 100 Gold Coins
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Five pirates have obtained 100 gold coins and have to divide up the loot. The pirates are all extremely intelligent, treacherous and selfish (especially the captain)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The captain always proposes a distribution of the loot. All pirates vote on the proposal, and if half the crew or more go "Aye", the loot is divided as proposed, as no pirate would be willing to take on the captain without superior force on their side."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If the captain fails to obtain support of at least half his crew (which includes himself), he faces a mutiny, and all pirates will turn against him and make him walk the plank. The pirates start over again with the next senior pirate as captain."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the maximum number of coins the captain can keep without risking his life?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The captain says he will take 98 coins, and will give one coin to the third most senior pirate and another coin to the most junior pirate. He then explains his decision in a manner like this..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If there were 2 pirates, pirate 2 being the most senior, he would just vote for himself and that would be 50% of the vote, so he's obviously going to keep all the money for himself."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If there were 3 pirates, pirate 3 has to convince at least one other person to join in his plan. Pirate 3 would take 99 gold coins and give 1 coin to pirate 1. Pirate 1 knows if he does not vote for pirate 3, then he gets nothing, so obviously is going to vote for this plan."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If there were 4 pirates, pirate 4 would give 1 coin to pirate 2, and pirate 2 knows if he does not vote for pirate 4, then he gets nothing, so obviously is going to vote for this plan."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"As there are 5 pirates, pirates 1 & 3 had obviously better vote for the captain, or they face choosing nothing or risking death."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If there were 2 pirates, pirate 2 being the most senior, he would just vote for himself and that would be 50% of the vote, so he's obviously going to keep all the money for himself."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

title: 100 Gold Coins
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Five pirates have obtained 100 gold coins and have to divide up the loot. The pirates are all extremely intelligent, treacherous and selfish (especially the captain).
The captain always proposes a distribution of the loot. All pirates vote on the proposal, and if half the crew or more go "Aye", the loot is divided as proposed, as no pirate would be willing to take on the captain without superior force on their side.
If the captain fails to obtain support of at least half his crew (which includes himself), he faces a mutiny, and all pirates will turn against him and make him walk the plank. The pirates start over again with the next senior pirate as captain.
What is the maximum number of coins the captain can keep without risking his life?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The captain says he will take 98 coins, and will give one coin to the third most senior pirate and another coin to the most junior pirate. He then explains his decision in a manner like this...
If there were 2 pirates, pirate 2 being the most senior, he would just vote for himself and that would be 50% of the vote, so he's obviously going to keep all the money for himself.
If there were 3 pirates, pirate 3 has to convince at least one other person to join in his plan. Pirate 3 would take 99 gold coins and give 1 coin to pirate 1. Pirate 1 knows if he does not vote for pirate 3, then he gets nothing, so obviously is going to vote for this plan.
If there were 4 pirates, pirate 4 would give 1 coin to pirate 2, and pirate 2 knows if he does not vote for pirate 4, then he gets nothing, so obviously is going to vote for this plan.
As there are 5 pirates, pirates 1 & 3 had obviously better vote for the captain, or they face choosing nothing or risking death."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
